ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
River Ranch Fresh Foods, LLC. (RRFF) committed to complying with all of the regulatory requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program. RRFF has developed their Risk Management Plan / Process Safety Management (RMP/PSM) Manual to document RRFF policies addressing the implementation of these regulations. The PSM sections pertain to the prevention of accidental releases and include the Process Hazard Analysis study and procedures for operating, training, maintenance, emergency response, and others. The RMP sections pertain to management systems and include the Hazard Assessment (Offsite Consequence Analysis) Report.

STATIONARY SOURCE ACTIVITIES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
The RRFF El Centro facilities provides product cooling, processing, and short-term storage for fresh vegetables. 
 
The facilities are located in an industrial area of El Centro on a contiguous property split by a city street. Ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the D1 Dock Main Plant Refrigeration System and the P1 P

rocessing Main Plant Refrigeration System. The ammonia quantity in each of these systems is over 10,000 lbs each.

In addition to the Main Plant Systems, five (5) smaller systems (under 10,000 lbs each) are the property. Other than this paragraph, these systems are not addressed in the EPA RMP submission; however, they are addressed in the RMP as required by the California Accidental Release and Prevention Program (CalARP).

The refrigeration systems are direct, mechanical refrigeration systems (?System?). The original facilities were built prior to 1990 and have been expanded and modified since then. The ammonia equipment is located outside or in the Refrigerated Rooms. 

A portion of the ammonia equipment is portable and is moved on and off site annually. The local produce season typically runs November through April. The interconnecting piping between the portable components and the Main Plants are permanently mounted.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT
The regulation requires that the Worst-Case Release Scenario use the ammonia quantity in the largest vessel or pipe.

NOTE: It is important to consider that the Worst-Case Scenario is extremely unlikely to occur since this scenario does not consider any safety features of the system  - in either design or operation.  The scenario parameters are established by the regulation to provide uniformity for dialog between the industry, community, and regulatory agencies.

The regulation allows the facility to select the Alternate-Case Scenario.

PREVENTION PROGRAM
RRFF's Prevention Program is described in the RMP/PSM Manual. The RMP Prevention Program is equivalent to OSHA's Process Safety Management Program (PSM). The Prevention Program implemented by RRFF is essential to help prevent releases and to minimize the effects if a release does occur.

Key objectives of RRFF's Prevention Program are briefly described below:

1.Maintain current and complete refrigeration system technical information. (Addressed under the Process Safety Informa

tion chapter)
2.Provde thorough team evaluation of the refrigeration system. The evaluation considers a number of potential problems including: mechanical problems, human errors, and external events (e.g., earthquakes). All safety recommendations developed by the team are reviewed and addressed by RRFF. (Addressed under Process Hazard Analysis chapter.)
3.Written procedures and policies that establish how the refrigeration system should be operated and maintained and how to investigate accidental releases. (Addressed under Operating Procedures, Mechanical Integrity, and Incident Investigation chapters.)
4.Certification of refrigeration operators to safely operate the refrigeration system. RRFF certifies operators following completion of operator training and RRFF's confirmation of the operator's ability apply what they have learned. (Addressed under Training chapter.)
5.Employee involvement in the Prevention Program. This is addressed on two levels. First, refrigeration equipment operators participate in the planning and evaluation of the Prevention Programs (e.g., Process Hazard Analysis study team, writing and/or reviewing operating procedures, Incident Investigation team, etc.). This involvement encourages ownership of the Prevention Program and positively affects the operators' day-to-day activities.  
Second, all RRFF employees (direct hires and contract) at this facility receive ammonia awareness training. Additionally, they have access to the RMP/PSM information. These activities improve the overall safety of the employees. (Both levels are addressed under Employee Participation chapter)
6.Implementation of additional measures when changes are planned  (procedural or mechanical). These measures begin before any changes are made and may include a Process Hazard Analysis, operator training, and Process Safety Information updates plus other measures required by RRFF's Management of Change Procedure.  
If a mechanical change is required and for maintenance contra

cts, RRFF has a procedure for selecting a contractor based on the company's experience and safety history. Additionally, if welding, grinding, or other "Hot Work" occurs inside the building and close to the refrigeration system, a RRFF Hot Work permit is required. The purpose of the permit and the associated Hot Work procedure is to minimize the possibility of a fire. 
Following completion of a mechanical change, a pre-startup safety review is required before the system can be started. (These areas are addressed under Management of Change, Contractor Qualifications, Hot Work Permit, and Pre-Start-up Safety Review chapters.)
7.Verification of RRFF's compliance with the RMP/PSM program. This self-audit process is an important tool to confirm whether each of the elements in the Prevention Program  (and the Risk Management Program) has been implemented and properly documented by RRFF personnel. RRFF has established a Management System procedure to address any shortcomings, which the audit may find. (Addressed under Compliance Audit chapter.)   
8.Minimize employee injury and illness. (Addressed under RRFF's Illness and Injury Prevention Program.)


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The RRFF facility  had  no reportable accidental ammonia releases in the last five years.

  
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
RRFF's Emergency Response Program is described in their Emergency Response Plan for the El Centro facility.

This plan includes planned responses and procedures for evacuations, notifying responders and governmental agencies. The plan also includes first aid procedures for immediate care and instructions for follow-up medical care when necessary. The plan addresses training requirements for employees including production employees, supervisors, managers, and operators. Evacuation drills are an important part of the training. 

Under RRFF's Emergency Response policy, RRFF employees who have been trained as "First Responders" may initially respond to releases that can be addressed w

ithout entering the danger area (i.e. de-energizing equipment). RRFF will evacuate affected area, begin notification process, and rely on off-site responders (e.g., the fire department, portable ammonia equipment supplier and/or refrigeration contractor).

 
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study team developed recommendations to improve safety.
Key recommendations identified during study include:
?Establish additional written procedures for practices and maintenance
? Install additional eyewash stations
?Require Operators and Technicians to carry portable eye wash bottles when working on roof
?Add lighting at ice generator, vacuum tubes and hydrocooler
?Add catwalks to improve equipment accessibility
?Add roof accesses for roof top valve station access
?Install additional emergency kill button  for safe shutdown of equipment
?Label piping, valves and equipment, including electrical breakers
?Expand alarm system
?Expand preventative maintenance (PM) program
?Fence HPR area of Dock System
?Install bollards for additional equipment protection
?Measures to reduce dirt infiltration at the Dock monitor control center (MCC)
?Measures to prevent water collection in underground electrical vaults
?Replace old PRVs and address relief discharge header deficiency 
?Critical valve tagging 
?Replace vessels where ASME documentation cannot be located. 
?Install oil  pot and spring closing valves at oil pots and oil drain points.


RRFF has reviewed recommendations and scheduled implementation the recommended measures
